etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French, from Latin a parte ‘at the side’

definitions: (of two or more people or things) separated by a distance; at a specified distance from each other in time or space

examples.text: two stone gateposts some thirty feet apart
the two sides remained far apart on the issue
his parents are now living apart
countries as far apart as New Zealand and the US

definitions: to or on one side; at a distance from the main body

examples.text: Isabel stepped away from Joanna and stood apart
their religious commitment sets them apart

definitions: used after a noun to indicate that someone or something has distinctive qualities that mark them out from other people or things
used after a noun to indicate that someone or something has been dealt with sufficiently or is being excluded from what follows

examples.text: Alaska apart, much of America's energy business concentrates on producing gas

definitions: so as to be shattered; into pieces

examples.text: he leapt out of the car just before it was blown apart
